node.title: How Saboteurs Took Over the G.O.P.
node.description: Republican obstructionism is getting even more naked.Â
node.content: ["With everything else going on \u2014 the likely imminent demise of Roe v. Wade, the revelation that Donald Trump knew he had tested positive for the coronavirus before he debated Joe Biden, and more \u2014 I don\u2019t know how many readers are aware that the U.S. government could be forced to shut down this weekend. A last-minute deal may have averted that crisis \u2014 although that isn\u2019t certain \u2014 but in any case another crisis will follow in a couple of weeks: The government is expected to hit its debt ceiling in the middle of this month, and failure to raise the ceiling would wreak havoc not just with governance but with America\u2019s financial reputation.", "The thing is, the federal government isn\u2019t having any problem raising money \u2014 in fact, it can borrow at interest rates well below the inflation rate, so that the real cost of servicing additional federal debt is actually negative. Instead, this is all about politics. Both continuing government funding and raising the debt limit are subject to the filibuster, and many Republican senators won\u2019t support doing either unless Democrats meet their demands.", "And what has Republicans so exercised that they\u2019re willing to endanger both the functioning of our government and the nation\u2019s financial stability? Whatever they may say, they aren\u2019t taking a stand on principle \u2014 or at least, not on any principle other than the proposition that even duly elected Democrats have no legitimate right to govern.", "In some ways we\u2019ve seen this movie before. Republicans led by Newt Gingrich partly shut down the government in 1995-96 in an attempt to extract concessions from President Bill Clinton. G.O.P. legislators created a series of funding crises under President Barack Obama, again in a (partly successful) attempt to extract policy concessions. Creating budget crises whenever a Democrat sits in the White House has become standard Republican operating procedure.", "Yet current G.O.P. attempts at extortion are both more naked and less rational than what happened during the Obama years.", "Under Obama, leading Republicans claimed that their fiscal brinkmanship was motivated by concerns about budget deficits. Some of us argued even at the time that self-proclaimed deficit hawks were phonies, that they didn\u2019t actually care about government debt \u2014 a view validated by their silence when the Trump administration blew up the deficit \u2014 and that they actually wanted to see the economy suffer on Obama\u2019s watch. But they maintained enough of a veneer of responsibility to fool many commentators.", "This time, Republican obstructionists aren\u2019t even pretending to care about red ink. Instead, they\u2019re threatening to shut everything down unless the Biden administration abandons its efforts to fight the coronavirus with vaccine mandates.", "What\u2019s that about? As many observers have pointed out, claims that opposition to vaccine mandates (and similar opposition to mask mandates) is about maintaining personal freedom don\u2019t stand up to any kind of scrutiny. No reasonable definition of freedom includes the right to endanger other people\u2019s health and lives because you don\u2019t feel like taking basic precautions.", "Furthermore, actions by Republican-controlled state governments, for example in Florida and Texas, show a party that isn\u2019t so much pro-freedom as it is pro-Covid. How else can you explain attempts to prevent private businesses \u2014 whose freedom to choose was supposed to be sacrosanct \u2014 from requiring that their workers be vaccinated, or offers of special unemployment benefits for the unvaccinated?", "In other words, the G.O.P. doesn\u2019t look like a party trying to defend liberty; it looks like a party trying to block any effective response to a deadly disease. Why is it doing this?", "To some extent it surely reflects a coldly cynical political calculation. Voters tend to blame whichever party holds the White House for anything bad that happens on its watch, which creates an incentive for a sufficiently ruthless party to engage in outright sabotage. Sure enough, Republicans who fought all efforts to contain the coronavirus are now attacking the Biden administration for failing to end the pandemic.", "But trying to shut down the government to block vaccinations seems like overreach, even for hardened cynics. It\u2019s notable that Mitch McConnell, whom nobody could accuse of being a do-gooder, isn\u2019t part of the anti-vaccine caucus.", "What seems to be happening instead goes beyond cold calculation. As I\u2019ve pointed out in the past, Republican politicians now act like apparatchiks in an authoritarian regime, competing to take ever more extreme positions as a way to demonstrate their loyalty to the cause \u2014 and to The Leader. Catering to anti-vaccine hysteria, doing all they can to keep the pandemic going, has become something Republicans do to remain in good standing within the party.", "The result is that one of America\u2019s two major political parties isn\u2019t just refusing to help the nation deal with its problems; it\u2019s actively working to make the country ungovernable.", "And I hope the rest of us haven\u2019t lost the ability to be properly horrified at this spectacle."]
